column2: This movie is so creative! The way they visualize the mind is genius.
Bing Bong fading away in the memory dump is the saddest moment in Pixar history. I will not be taking questions.
Anger is my favorite character. He's so relatable when the pizza place only has broccoli pizza.
The core memories becoming sad and making the personality islands crumble was such a great visual for depression.
I love the concept of the 'islands of personality'.
Joy finally realizing that Sadness is essential for Riley to process her emotions and connect with her parents is such a beautiful message.
The train of thought is such a clever idea.
The moment Riley's new core memories are a mix of emotions, not just one color, shows her growing up. So smart.
Disgust is hilarious. 'Congratulations San Francisco, you've ruined pizza!'
The abstract thought sequence was so trippy and creative.
The scene with the imaginary boyfriend is so funny. 'I would die for Riley.'
Joy and Sadness getting sucked out of headquarters is the moment the whole movie kicks into high gear.
This movie should be required viewing for understanding emotions.
The ending, where Riley finally breaks down and tells her parents how she feels, is so cathartic.
The world inside Riley's mind is so detailed and well-thought-out.
Bing Bong's sacrifice to get Joy back to headquarters... I'm tearing up just thinking about it.
The 'dream productions' studio is a hilarious take on how dreams are made.
The way the family islands shut down one by one as Riley gets more depressed is heartbreaking.
Sadness was the hero all along and Joy just couldn't see it. Great character development.
The control panels of the parents' minds at the end was the funniest scene in the whole movie.
I love how each emotion has a specific job to protect Riley.
Joy's journey to understand that Riley needs to feel sad sometimes is the core of the film.
The memory dump is such a scary and sad concept.
The moment Sadness makes Bing Bong feel better by just listening to him is so important.
The animation is so bright and colorful, which is a great contrast to the sadder themes.
The new, expanded control panel at the end, with a 'puberty' button, is a perfect sequel setup.
The idea that some memories fade while jingles from commercials stay forever is painfully true.
The way Riley's personality is literally built on her core memories is a brilliant concept.
Fear is basically my spirit animal. 'We did not die today, I call that an unqualified success.'
When Joy looks at all the sad memories and realizes they led to happy moments... that's the big turning point.
This movie has so much emotional intelligence.
The climax of the film is literally Joy letting Sadness take control. So powerful.
The 'facts and opinions' getting mixed up in the train of thought was a clever gag.
The way Riley's inner world reflects her outer turmoil is so well done.
I think everyone has a 'circle of sadness' they have to deal with.
The end credits showing the inside of other people's (and animals') minds was hilarious.
This is one of those movies that's great for kids but even better for adults.
The moment Goofball Island falls is the first sign that things are seriously wrong.
The way Sadness can't help but touch memories and make them sad is a great metaphor.
The final scene, where Riley is happy again but in a more complex way, is a perfect resolution.
The casting for the emotions is perfect. Amy Poehler as Joy is iconic.
The way they fall into the memory dump is the film's lowest point, making their escape so much better.
The concept of 'dream duty' is so funny.
The fact that the core memories create the personality islands is a really strong visual metaphor.
The movie does a great job of showing that it's okay to not be okay.
The final core memory being a mix of joy and sadness is the whole message of the film.
The friendship between Joy and Sadness by the end is so earned.
The mind workers cleaning out the faded memories is a little sad.
The 'Imagination Land' sequence was so creative and fun.
The ending shows that our emotions get more complex as we grow up, and that's a good thing.
The way the headquarters gets dark and gray when Joy is gone is very effective.
The moment Riley gets the idea to run away is genuinely scary because you feel how lost she is.
This movie is a visual representation of therapy. So good.
Bing Bong realizing he has to stay behind so Joy can make it is the ultimate sacrifice.
The contrast between Joy's optimism and Sadness's realism is the heart of the movie's conflict.
The film teaches that sadness is not just okay, but necessary for empathy and connection.
The way Riley's personality islands are rebuilt at the end, bigger and more complex, is beautiful.
The design of each emotion is so distinct and perfect.
Joy's desperate attempt to keep Riley happy at all costs is actually what causes the main problem.
The movie is so clever on so many levels.
The reunion at the end, when Joy and Sadness return, is so triumphant.
The way the memories are stored in these little glass balls is a great visual.
The moment when Joy and Bing Bong sing the rocket song to try and fly out of the dump... devastating.
The film is a beautiful and nuanced look at mental health for all ages.
The final scene shows that it's the balance of all emotions that makes us who we are.
The way Riley's happy memories turn sad is a perfect depiction of nostalgia and homesickness.
The 'Cloud Town' scene is a small but really funny moment.
The fact that Sadness was the only one who could get Riley to open up to her parents is the whole point.
A truly special and important film from Pixar.
The climax isn't a big fight, it's an emotional breakthrough. And that's why it's so good.
The idea of a 'headquarters' for your emotions is brilliant.
The moment the idea lightbulb goes off for Anger to make Riley run away is a major turning point.
The movie is a journey of self-acceptance for both Riley and Joy.
The way they visualize how a memory is made is so cool.
Bing Bong is a character that will stay with you forever.
The ending doesn't just put things back to normal, it shows that Riley has grown and changed.
The train of thought stopping when Riley sleeps is a nice little detail.
The way Joy has to literally drag Sadness around is a perfect metaphor for dealing with depression.
This movie is a modern classic.
The final hug between Riley and her parents, prompted by Sadness, is what saves everything.
The jokes about the gum commercial are so relatable.
The way the core memories define her personality is such a strong central idea.
The voice acting is phenomenal across the board.
The ending shows that happiness is more meaningful when you also allow yourself to feel sad.
The world inside the mind is one of the most creative settings ever.
Bing Bong's sacrifice is the emotional gut-punch of the entire movie.
This movie is a visual and emotional rollercoaster.
The core message that all your emotions are valid and important is so powerful.
The way Riley's personality literally crumbles when she's sad is a brilliant visual.
The film's resolution is so mature and emotionally intelligent.
The creativity on display is off the charts.
The moment Joy realizes the value of Sadness is a huge breakthrough for her character.
This film is a beautiful exploration of the human mind.
The ending brings all the themes together perfectly, showing how joy and sadness can coexist.
One of the most original and moving stories Pixar has ever told.
The way the control panel gets more complex at the end signifies Riley's emotional growth.
